data.title: New Details Released in Case of Missing Mom, Kids in Canadian Wilderness
data.meta_description: Astrid Schiller and her three boys were reported missing in December, but have been reportedly seen multiple times since.
data.text:
Canadian police are in a frantic search for a mother and her three sons who vanished from Ontario in December.

Astrid Schiller, 55, is accused of abducting her own children and has been on the run for months.

The mother was reported missing along with her three boys – Leon, 12, Christopher, 11, and Thomas, 9 – from Ontario in December.

After months with few reported sightings, the Royal Canadian Mounted Police released news Saturday that the group had been spotted multiple times in recent weeks and the mother had been arrested before being released.

Now the search is on once more for the group, believed to be camping in parks around Saskatchewan province.

RCMP had a breakthrough in its search for Schiller after getting a report at 2 a.m. on June 16 that she was trying to cross the border at Boissevain into the U.S.

Officers detained the mother and took the children into care in Forrest, Manitoba, but they released her soon after, stating that the arrest warrant issued in Ontario didn't extend into the other province.

In the early hours of June 17, police were told that the children were no longer at the care home, and it was believed Schiller had taken them once again.

The group was then spotted in Assiniboia before heading to Pine Cree Regional Park in Saskatchewan on June 19, the RCMP said.

On Friday, June 21, an abandoned vehicle was found at the park. The white 2018 Mercedes GLC was believed to belong to Schiller, but there was no sign of her or the boys.

Newsweek reached out to RCMP Monday morning via email.

When did the Schillers disappear?

It isn't entirely clear exactly when Schiller and her three boys vanished.

The Toronto Sun reported that they vanished sometime in December, but said that police had not given many details away about the timeline.

Initially, it is believed Schiller communicated with police but later withdrew that cooperation.

An arrest warrant was issued on Jan. 24.

Astrid Schiller is a parent's rights activist

Press Progress reported in January that Schiller was part of a Facebook group called "Stand4Thee", which is known for creating pseudo-legal documents on conspiracies relating to public health measures, vaccines and education.

The outlet claimed Schiller had actively participated in the group's Zoom meetings and that she had written to one of her son's schools to say he would not participate in discussions on his gender or sexuality.

Other complaints included standing against raising an LGBTQ+ pride flag at the school and the creation of a gender neutral bathroom.

In the meeting witnessed by Press Progress, the group reportedly discussed how liberal views were a "demonic war" against Christian values.

In its original press release on the missing group, Durham Regional Police Service said it did not believe there was any risk posed to the children.

Following the incident at the border, DRPS said it was continuing to assist in the search for the group "in any manner necessary".
